articles.headline: Next-Day Mail Faces Postal Service Cuts
articles.snippet: Proposed cuts would close about half of the nearly 500 mail processing centers across the country as early as March.
articles.abstract: Proposed cuts would close about half of the nearly 500 mail processing centers across the country as early as March.
articles.lead_paragraph: The post office had bad news on Monday for all those who like to pop a check into the mail to pay a bill due the next day: don’t count on it.

articles.headline: In Ireland, Austerity Is Praised but Painful
articles.snippet: From the outside, the country is hailed as an example of economic survival, but its citizens say they feel burdened.
articles.abstract: From the outside, the country is hailed as an example of economic survival, but its citizens say they feel burdened.
articles.lead_paragraph: DUBLIN — As European leaders scramble to overcome the Continent’s debt crisis, many are pointing to Ireland as a model for how to get out of the troubles.

articles.headline: S.&P. Warns Euro Zone of Ratings Downgrades
articles.snippet: Fifteen euro zone nations had their credit ratings placed on a watch list with “negative implications” on Monday.
articles.abstract: Fifteen euro zone nations had their credit ratings placed on a watch list with “negative implications” on Monday.
articles.lead_paragraph: Standard & Poor’s on Monday warned that it might strip the euro zone’s two biggest economies, Germany and France, of their top-notch AAA long-term credit ratings because of the Continent’s economic crisis. The agency also said the ratings of 13 other euro zone countries were vulnerable.
articles.byline: By Graham Bowley and Julie Creswell

articles.headline: Concerns Over Merger in Pharmacy
articles.snippet: An antitrust hearing will examine assertions by opponents that competition and costs will suffer if a deal between Express Scripts and Medco Health Solutions proceeds.
articles.abstract: An antitrust hearing will examine assertions by opponents that competition and costs will suffer if a deal between Express Scripts and Medco Health Solutions proceeds.
articles.lead_paragraph: Express Scripts’ proposed $29 billion acquisition of Medco Health Solutions is expected to face intensified scrutiny on Tuesday when a Senate panel examines potential antitrust concerns raised by the merger of two of the country’s largest pharmacy benefit managers.
articles.byline: By Reed Abelson and Natasha Singer

articles.headline: Wal-Mart Debate Rages in India
articles.snippet: Many in India fear that its local stores will be hurt if Wal-Mart is allowed to open American-style retail stores.
articles.abstract: Many in India fear that its local stores will be hurt if Wal-Mart is allowed to open American-style retail stores.
articles.lead_paragraph: JALANDHAR, India — For multinational merchants like Wal-Mart, it seemed to be the long-awaited opportunity to jump into India with both feet. But on Monday that moment appeared to be delayed once again.

articles.headline: Around the World in One Movie: Film Financing’s Global Future
articles.snippet: Sophisticated filmmakers who once relied on American studios for backing are turning to a globe-straddling independent finance system for their most expensive projects.
articles.abstract: Sophisticated filmmakers who once relied on American studios for backing are turning to a globe-straddling independent finance system for their most expensive projects.
articles.lead_paragraph: POTSDAM, Germany — The German craftsmen on Stage 15 in the Babelsberg studio were hard at work on a recent afternoon building a dystopian Korean slum, the thud of a nail gun and a whiff of sawdust in the air. Next door, Andy and Lana Wachowski, the American-born team behind the “Matrix” movies, were filming black-clad storm troopers from an imagined future for their latest feature, “Cloud Atlas.”
articles.byline: By Nicholas Kulish and Michael Cieply

articles.headline: Aid Agencies in Afghanistan Fear Reversals After U.S. Exit
articles.snippet: Civilian aid workers worry that Afghanistan will be abandoned and that the hard-earned development gains will be reversed.
articles.abstract: Civilian aid workers worry that Afghanistan will be abandoned and that the hard-earned development gains will be reversed.
articles.lead_paragraph: KABUL, Afghanistan — Even as President Hamid Karzai beseeched nations at a conference in Germany on Monday to continue aid to Afghanistan for another decade, the American withdrawal from Afghanistan is already being felt among civilian aid workers, raising anxieties that Afghanistan will be abandoned and that the hard-earned development gains will be reversed.

articles.headline: Many Workers in Public Sector Retiring Sooner
articles.snippet: The change reflects demographics, in part, but also government cost-cutting that has resulted in less generous pay and benefits.
articles.abstract: The change reflects demographics, in part, but also government cost-cutting that has resulted in less generous pay and benefits.
articles.lead_paragraph: MADISON, Wis. — As states and cities struggle to resolve paralyzing budget shortfalls by sending workers on unpaid furloughs, freezing salaries and extracting larger contributions for health benefits and pensions, a growing number of public-sector workers are finding fewer reasons to stay.

articles.headline: Vermont Rebounding Quickly From Hurricane Irene
articles.snippet: In the three months since Hurricane Irene, the state repaired and reopened some 500 miles of damaged road, replaced a dozen bridges with temporary structures and repaired about 200 altogether.
articles.abstract: In the three months since Hurricane Irene, the state repaired and reopened some 500 miles of damaged road, replaced a dozen bridges with temporary structures and repaired about 200 altogether.
articles.lead_paragraph: BETHEL, Vt. — The raging White River that chewed up seven miles of Route 107 has gone back to being tame and lovely.

articles.headline: Rare Attacks on Shiites Kill Scores in Afghanistan
articles.snippet: Bombers struck Shiite religious observances on Tuesday, in the first such sectarian attacks since the fall of the Taliban.
articles.abstract: Bombers struck Shiite religious observances on Tuesday, in the first such sectarian attacks since the fall of the Taliban.
articles.lead_paragraph: KABUL, Afghanistan — A Pakistan-based extremist group claimed responsibility for a series of coordinated bombings aimed at Afghan Shiites on Tuesday, in what many feared was an attempt to further destabilize Afghanistan by adding a new dimension of strife to a country that, though battered by a decade of war, has been free of sectarian conflict.

articles.headline: The Culture Was Corrupt at Olympus, Panel Finds
articles.snippet: A third-party panel issued a harshly worded report, but reiterated that it had found no evidence of organized crime involvement in the Olympus scandal.
articles.abstract: A third-party panel issued a harshly worded report, but reiterated that it had found no evidence of organized crime involvement in the Olympus scandal.
articles.lead_paragraph: TOKYO — An outside panel appointed by Olympus to investigate its financial scandal issued a harsh report Tuesday, calling the company’s recently departed management “rotten to the core.”
articles.byline: By Hiroko Tabuchi and Keith Bradsher

articles.headline: Tiny Tax on Financial Trades Gains Advocates
articles.snippet: The so-called Robin Hood tax — a tiny levy on trades in the financial markets that would take money from the banks and give it to the world’s poor — has attracted an array of influential champions.
articles.abstract: The so-called Robin Hood tax — a tiny levy on trades in the financial markets that would take money from the banks and give it to the world’s poor — has attracted an array of influential champions.
articles.lead_paragraph: They call it the Robin Hood tax — a tiny levy on trades in the financial markets that would take money from the banks and give it to the world’s poor.
articles.byline: By Steven Greenhouse and Graham Bowley
